title.narrative: Support to OHCHR for 15 Years of Maputo Protocol Event
Support to OHCHR for 15 Years of Maputo Protocol Event

description.narrative:
FNs kontor för mänskliga rättigheter (UNOHCHR) har vänt sig till Sida för att ansöka om SEK 2.393.772 för att organisera ett tre dagars event i syfte att fira att det i år är 15 år sedan Maputo protokollet för kvinnors rättigheter, vilket är ett tilläggsprotokoll till AUs Charter om Folkens och de Mänskliga Rättigheterna, antogs. Firandet kommer ske i Maputo, Mocambique, i oktober 2018.
Evenemanget syftar till att fira de framsteg som har gjorts på kontinenten när det gäller kvinnors rättigheter och uppmärksamma de utmaningar som återstår. I fokus för diskussionerna kommer vara: vägen framåt för att säkerställa universell ratificering, avlägsnande av reservationer, "domesticering" och genomförande av Maputo-protokollet, inklusive strategier för mobilisering av stöd. OHCHR organiserar programmet tillsammans med AU: s jämställdhets- och utvecklingsdirektorat, AU: s särskilda rapportör för kvinnors rättigheter samt nätverket Solidarity for African Women’s Rights (SOAWR) mot bakgrund av insikten att kontinental ratificering och genomförande av Maputo-protokollet kräver ett integrerat och kollektivt engagemang från alla intressenter.
Den totala budgeten för insatsen är SEK 2.818.550 (or USD 322.043) till vilket OHCHC själva bidrar med c:a SEK 262.563 (USD 30.000) och AUCs jämställdhetsdirektorat med SEK 437.605 (USD 50.000).

The Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR) has applied to Sida for funding of SEK 2,393,772 to organize a three day event to celebrate the 15 Years of the adopton of the Protocol to the African Charter on Human and Peoples’ Rights on the Rights of Women in Africa also known as the Maputo Protocol in Mozambique in October 2018.
The event aims at celebrating the achievements that has been made on the continent on women’s rights and outstanding challenges. The way forward to secure universal ratification, removal of reservations, domestication and implementation of the Maputo Protocol including strategies for mobilizing support will also be the focus of the event. OHCHR is organizing the program with the AU Women, Gender and Development Directorate (WGDD), the AU Special Rapporteur on Rights of Women and Solidarity for African Women’s Rights (SOAWR) in recognition that continental wide ratification, implementation and domestication of the Maputo Protocol requires an integrated and collective engagement of all stakeholders.
The Intervention's total budget is SEK 2,818,550 (USD 322,042.75) out of which OHCHR own's fund is approximatley SEK 262, 563 (30,000USD) and SEK 437, 605 (50,000 USD) is contributed by African Union Women Gender and Development Directorate (WGDD).

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: I. the 15th anniversary celebrations and High-Level Consultation to accelerate the ratification, domestication and implementation of the Maputo Protocol The UN Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights East African Regional Office (OHCHR-EARO) has organized the event to celebrate 15th anniversary of the Maputo Protocol in December 2018 in Addis Ababa in partnership with the African Union Women, Gender and Development Directorate (AU WGDD), the AU Special Rapporteur on the Rights of Women in Africa, United Nations Development Program (UNDP) and Solidarity for African Women’s Rights (SOAWR). The event was attended by over 150 participants with representatives from Gender Ministries, the UN human rights mechanisms, including the UN Special Rapporteur on Violence Against Women, the Chairperson of the Committee on the Elimination of Discrimination against Women (CEDAW), INGOs, CSOs and Member States. Member States deliberated on shared challenges and opportunities with regard to the ratification of the Maputo Protocol, examples of legal provisions promulgated, programs implemented and institutions established that advance the provisions laid out in the Maputo Protocol. Participants (Member States, along with the AU, UN, CSOs and other partners) recommitted to work collectively towards the promotion of women’s rights and gender equality on the continent. South Africa agreed to remove its reservations on the protocol during the meeting which could be considered as one of the key positive outcomes of the event if it is follwed up with concrete steps. (the full outcome report of the consultation/deliberation is attached) II. Adoption of 'All for Maputo Protocol Roadmap' and action plan A document referred as ‘All for Maputo Protocol Roadmap (2019-2028)' was developed by the AU, OHCHR and other partners during the meeting which identified 5 strategic priorities for full enforcement of the Maputo protocol which are universal ratification, greater domestication and implementation, popularization, accountability and partnerships. The document also outlined the relevant actors and key strategies and steps that need to be taken over the next ten years. Country profiles and accompanying advocacy strategies for all countries who are yet to ratify the protocol (Burundi, Central African Republic, Chad, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Madagascar, Niger, Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic, Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan and Tunisia) as well as an action plan for in-country advocacy missions to accelerate ratification were developed. III. Other outputs The final report has highlighted additional efforts and processes the Sida funds has contributed to even though they were not part of the initial plan. These include - Establishment of a working Group for French-speaking human rights Commissions on Gender and women's rights - Support to the AU Special Rapporteur on Rights of Women in Africa and AU WGDD in different engagements including the UN Special Rapporteur on Violence Against Women regional meeting on international and regional mechanisms, 64th ordinary session of African Commission on Human and Peoples' Rights and the 38th NGOs forum in Egypt - Provision of technical and financial support to the continental women activist network, Gender is my Agenda (GIMAC) - Development of OHCHR/AU/UN Women/UNHCHR Report on strengthening compliance and norm-monitoring of the AU African Governance Architecture and African Peace and Security Architecture focusing on ‘Refugees, Returnees and Internally Displaced Persons in Africa: Towards Durable Solutions to Forced Displacement of Women and Girls’ (the report is not pubished yet)
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
